questions.text:
Which among the following are Skeletal derivatives of 3rd pharyngeal arch?


	Greater cornu of hyoid
	Stylohyoid ligament
	Lesser cornu of hyoid
	Upper half of body of hyoid
	Lower half of body of hyoid
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1 and 5

 

Explanation:

Arch

Nerve of arch

Artery of arch

Skeletal derivatives

(Option D)

Muscles of arch

Third

Glossopharyngeal nerve
  • Common carotid artery
  • Internal carotid artery
  • Greater cornu of hyoid
  • Lower half of body of hyoid

 

Stylopharyngeus

questions.text:

	Fusion with caudal pharyngeal complex
	Formation of pharyngeal arches
	Thyroglossal duct formation
	Tuberculum impar is formed
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 2,4,3,1

 

Explanation:

 

Development of thyroid gland:

questions.text: Which of the following statements on double aortic arch is false?

choices.text: Right aortic arch passes in front of the trachea and esophagus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Right aortic arch passes in front of the trachea and esophagus

 

Explanation:

In a double aortic arch, the right aortic arch passes behind the trachea and esophagus, not in front of it.

 

Double aortic arch:

  • A developmental anomaly in which a vascular ring surrounds the trachea and esophagus.
  • The dorsal aorta is a midline artery dorsal to the gut
  • In normal development, the right dorsal aorta between the origin of the 7th cervical intersegmental artery and its fusion with the left dorsal aorta disappears.
  • In this case, the right dorsal aorta persisted.
  • The right aortic arch passes behind the trachea and esophagus. (Option D)
  • The left aortic arch passes in front of the trachea and esophagus, forming a vascular ring.
  • The vascular ring compresses the trachea and esophagus, leading to dyspnea and dysphagia

questions.text: Which pharyngeal arch primarily contributes to the development of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) First pharyngeal arch

 

Explanation:

Development of tongue: Begins around the fourth week of intrauterine life.

 

Anterior 2/3rd of tongue:

  • The development begins with the growth of medial swelling from the first pharyngeal arch known as tuberculum impar.
  • Gradually, two lateral lingual swellings start to grow in the 5th week from the same arch.
  • As the lateral swelling grows in size they eventually merge and overlap tuberculum impar leading to the formation of anterior 2/3rd of tongue.

 

Posterior 1/3rd of tongue:

  • From the mesoderm of the 2nd, 3rd and 4th pharyngeal arches, a median swelling known as hypobranchial eminence begins to develop and forms the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue.

 

Posterior most of tongue:

  • Develops from third median swelling arising from fourth pharyngeal arch.

 

 

Taste buds development:

  • First sign of taste bud development on lingual epithelium occurs at 8th week of gestation.
  • Between 9-11th week of gestation, many taste bud primordia develop.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with recurrent infections and signs of hypocalcemia. Investigation shows low levels of parathyroid hormone. The physician suspects an embryological defect. Which among the following could be a possible reason?

choices.text: Defect in the development of 1st pharyngeal pouch
Defect in the development of 2nd pharyngeal pouch
Defect in the development of 3rd pharyngeal pouch
Defect in the development of 5th pharyngeal pouch

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Defect in the development of 3rd pharyngeal pouch

 

Explanation:

  • Here the scenario is suggestive of defect in thymus development (recurrent infections) and defect in development of parathyroid gland ( signs of hypocalcemia and low levels of parathyroid hormone).
  • The 3rd pharyngeal pouch is responsible for the development of thymus and inferior parathyroid gland while the 4th pharyngeal pouch is responsible for the development of superior parathyroid gland. Hence, there could be a defect in only the 3rd pharyngeal pouch or defect could be in both 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches.

 

Pharyngeal arches, clefts and pouches

Pharyngeal arches
  • Pharyngeal arches are key structures in head and neck development, appearing in the fourth and fifth weeks as mesenchymal tissue bars.
  • They resemble gills but do not function as such in humans.
  • Pharyngeal arches are divided by pharyngeal clefts on the outside and pharyngeal pouches on the inside.
  • Pharyngeal pouches develop as outpocketings from the lateral walls of the pharynx and do not connect to the exterior, playing crucial roles in organ development.
  • Each arch incorporates neural crest cells essential for forming facial skeleton components, while mesoderm differentiates into facial and neck musculature.
  • Each arch has its own cranial nerve and artery.

Pharyngeal Pouches
  • Four Pairs (fifth is rudimentary)
  • First Pouch: Forms the middle ear cavity and Eustachian tube, contributes to the tympanic membrane.
  • Second Pouch: Develops into palatine tonsils; remnants persist as the tonsillar fossa.
  • Third Pouch: Dorsal wing becomes the inferior parathyroid gland; ventral wing forms the thymus, migrating to the thorax.
  • Fourth Pouch: Dorsal region forms the superior parathyroid gland; ventral region becomes the ultimobranchial body, integrating into the thyroid.

Pharyngeal Clefts
  • Five-week-old Embryo: Four clefts are present.
  • First Cleft: Does not form the external auditory meatus (EAM); instead, the EAM arises from surface ectoderm invagination. It eventually disappears due to overgrowth by the second arch.
  • Second, Third, and Fourth Clefts: Overgrown by the second arch, they lose exterior contact and may temporarily form the cervical sinus, which ultimately disappears.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles of the first pharyngeal arch are migratory?


	Mylohyoid
	Masseter
	Temporalis
	Tensor tympani
	Tensor palati
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) All except 4

 

Explanation:

Arch

Nerve of arch

Artery of arch

Skeletal derivatives

Muscles of arch

First

Maxillary (Sensory) and mandibular (Motor and sensory) branches of trigeminal nerve

Maxillary artery
  • Meckel's cartilage
    • Malleus
    • Incus
    • Anterior ligament of malleus
    • Sphenomandibular ligament
  • Mandible
  • Maxilla
  • Zygomatic
  • Palatine
  • Temporal (part)
  • Masseter
  • Temporalis
  • Medial pterygoid
  • Lateral pterygoids
  • Mylohyoid
  • Anterior belly of digastric
  • Tensor tympani, and
  • Tensor palati
 

All are migratory except T. tympani (Option D)

 

Pharyngeal arch

Muscles

First
  • Masseter
  • Temporalis
  • Medial pterygoid
  • Lateral pterygoids
  • Mylohyoid
  • Anterior belly of digastric
  • Tensor tympani, and
  • Tensor palati

Second
  • Stapedius
  • Stylohyoid
  • Posterior belly of digastric
  • Epicranius
  • Orbicularis oculi
  • Orbicularis oris
  • Zygomaticus
  • Buccinator
  • Nasal muscles
  • Platysma
  • Levator labii superioris, levator labii inferioris
  • Levator anguli oris
  • Auricular muscles

Third

Stylopharyngeus

Fourth
  • Larynx–Cricothyroid
  • Muscles of pharynx
  • Intrinsic muscles of soft palate except tensor palati

Sixth

All intrinsic muscles of larynx except cricothyroid

questions.text:
Which among the following are formed from Reichert's cartilage?


	Stapes
	Styloid process
	Stylohyoid ligament
	Lesser cornu of hyoid
	Upper half of body of hyoid
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) All the above

 

Explanation:

Arch

Nerve of arch

Artery of arch

Skeletal derivatives

Muscles of arch

Second

Facial nerve
  • Hyoid artery
  • Stapedial artery

The cartilage of the second arch (Reichert’s) forms the following: (Option A)

  • Stapes
  • Styloid process
  • Stylohyoid ligament
  • Lesser cornu of hyoid
  • Upper half of body of hyoid
  • Stapedius
  • Stylohyoid
  • Posterior belly of digastric
  • Epicranius
  • Orbicularis oculi
  • Orbicularis oris
  • Zygomaticus
  • Buccinator
  • Nasal muscles
  • Platysma
  • Levator labii superioris, levator labii inferioris
  • Levator anguli oris
  • Auricular muscles
 

All are migratory except stapedius, stylohyoid

questions.text:
Match the following pharyngeal arch to its corresponding nerve and artery derivatives. 

 


	
		
			
			Arch
			
			
			Nerve of arch
			
			
			Artery of arch
			
		
		
			
			1) Fourth
			
			
			a) Superior laryngeal nerve (Vagus)
			
			
			i) Arch of aorta
			
		
		
			
			ii) Subclavian artery
			
		
		
			
			2) Sixth
			
			
			b) Recurrent laryngeal nerve (vagus)
			
			
			iii) Ductus arteriosus
			
		
		
			
			iv) Pulmonary artery
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Option B and C

 

Explanation:

Arch

Nerve of arch

Artery of arch

Skeletal derivatives

Muscles of arch

Fourth

Superior laryngeal branch of vagus nerve
  • Arch of aorta (left side)
  • Subclavian artery (right side)
  • Thyroid
  • Cricoid
  • Corniculate
  • Cuneiform
  • Arytenoid
  • Thyrohyoid ligament
  • Epiglottis: From mesodermal core of hypobranchial eminence
  • Larynx: Cricothyroid
  • Muscles of pharynx
  • Intrinsic muscles of soft palate except tensor palati

Sixth

Recurrent laryngeal branch of vagus nerve
  • Ductus arteriosus (left side)
  • Pulmonary artery (right side)

All intrinsic muscles of larynx except cricothyroid

 

Note: High-pitch phonation is controlled by the cricothyroid muscle, which develops from the 4th pharyngeal arch and is innervated by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.

questions.text:
Match the pharyngeal arches to the nerves arising from it.

 


	
		
			
			Pharyngeal arch
			
			
			Nerve
			
		
		
			
			a. First
			
			
			1. Facial nerve
			
		
		
			
			b. Second
			
			
			2. Glossopharyngeal nerve
			
		
		
			
			c. Third
			
			
			3. Chorda tympani
			
		
		
			
			d. Sixth
			
			
			4. Recurrent laryngeal nerve
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) a-3, b-1, c-2, d-4

 

Explanation:

Pharyngeal Arch

Pretrematic Nerve

Post Trematic Nerve

First

Chorda tympani (branch of facial nerve)

Maxillary (sensory) and mandibular (motor & sensory) branches of trigeminal nerve (CN V)

Second

Possible: Tympanic branch of glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Facial nerve (CN VII)

Third

Possible: Auricular branch of vagus nerve (CN X)

Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Fourth

-

Superior laryngeal branch of vagus nerve (CN X)

Sixth

-

Recurrent laryngeal branch of vagus nerve (CN X)

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct pairing of the pharyngeal pouch with its derivative?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2nd pharyngeal pouch-Tonsillar fossa

 

Explanation:

Pharyngeal Pouch

Derivatives

1st Pharyngeal Pouch
  • Tympanic cavity
  • Auditory tube
  • Inner surface of the eardrum

2nd Pharyngeal Pouch
  • Palatine tonsil
  • Tonsillar fossa

3rd Pharyngeal Pouch
  • Thymus
  • Inferior parathyroid glands

4th Pharyngeal Pouch
  • Superior parathyroid glands
  • Thyroid gland

questions.text:
Match the pharyngeal arch with the artery developing from it


	
		
			
			Pharyngeal arch
			
			
			Artery
			
		
		
			
			a. First
			
			
			1. Hyoid artery
			
		
		
			
			b. Second
			
			
			2. Maxillary artery
			
		
		
			
			c. Third
			
			
			3. Arch of aorta
			
		
		
			
			d. Fourth
			
			
			4. Internal carotid artery
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) a-2, b-1, c-4, d-3

 

Explanation:

Pharyngeal Arch

Artery of Arch

First

Maxillary artery

Second

Hyoid artery, Stapedial artery

Third

Common carotid artery, Internal carotid artery

Fourth

Arch of aorta (left side), Subclavian artery (right side)

Sixth

Ductus arteriosus (left side), Pulmonary artery (right side)

questions.text: Which of the following nerves provides general sensation to the area of the tongue marked in blue?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lingual nerve

 

Explanation:

Nerve supply of tongue:

 

Sensory innervation:

Part of Tongue

General Sensation

Taste Sensation

Anterior two-third
  • Trigeminal nerve (V3) (specifically the lingual branch)
  • Chorda tympani branch of the facial nerve (CN VII)

Posterior one-third
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)
  • Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX)

Root of the tongue and the area around the epiglottis
  • Vagus nerve (CN X)
  • Vagus nerve (CN X)


 

Motor innervation:

  • The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) provides motor innervation to all of the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue except for the palatoglossus muscle, which is innervated by the vagus nerve (CN X).
